repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
`language.add()` also calls `language.register()` which violates the single responsibility principle and functional purity, and abets issues like #24531.

Although some of these issues are user error, what if someone does want `get_lang(ft) != ft` even when a parser named `ft` is available, or for any other legitimate reason wishes to load without registering?

In fact, several current usages are not even to load the parser, but to check whether it exists, so the registration side-effect is especially unnecessary.

This patch also "breaks" callers of `language.add()` to do `language.load()` without `language.register()`, but for those cases: https://xkcd.com/1172/

Closes: #24531

comment_regular_data.body:
> Although some of these issues are user error, what if someone does want get_lang(ft) != ft even when a parser named ft is available, or for any other legitimate reason wishes to load without registering?

It's assumed this can't happen, and I don't think we should change this unless there actually exists a parser named `ft` that doesn't map to `ft`.

I guess we still need to solve this problem.

> Because LanguageTree.new just called language.add(lang) which is language.add("typescriptreact"), and language module doesn't check that ft_to_lang already has a key named typescriptreact and a value tsx, it just override it.

This could be done by removing the default value on `opts.filetype`.

> This could be done by removing the default value on `opts.filetype`.

I considered that, and realized it'd still be a breaking change and would require relocating it to `add2` or `add_lang` function or something, which is why I took the opportunity to rethink the design a bit more from software engineering first principles.

But I'd be happy to go this route if that's where the consensus ends up.

Wait... I'm getting confused by this. I don't think it does override it.

```lua
register('typescriptreact', 'tsx')
add('typescriptreact')
```

Will create a mapping:
```
tsx -> typescriptreact
typescriptreact -> typescriptreact
```

Which is fine.

So I don't really understand the issue.

Wait, there's an even simpler fix for this. Simply don't `language.register()` if the parser lookup fails.

```diff
diff --git a/runtime/lua/vim/treesitter/language.lua b/runtime/lua/vim/treesitter/language.lua
index 9695e2c41..15bf666a1 100644
--- a/runtime/lua/vim/treesitter/language.lua
+++ b/runtime/lua/vim/treesitter/language.lua
@@ -82,9 +82,8 @@ function M.add(lang, opts)
     filetype = { filetype, { 'string', 'table' }, true },
   })
 
-  M.register(lang, filetype)
-
   if vim._ts_has_language(lang) then
+    M.register(lang, filetype)
     return
   end
 
@@ -102,6 +101,7 @@ function M.add(lang, opts)
   end
 
   vim._ts_add_language(path, lang, symbol_name)
+  M.register(lang, filetype)
 end
 
 --- @param x string|string[]
```

That being said, I still believe in SRP, but if this solution is preferred I can make a different PR.

> Wait... I'm getting confused by this. I don't think it does override it.
> 
> ```lua
> register('typescriptreact', 'tsx')
> add('typescriptreact')
> ```
> 
> Will create a mapping:
> 
> ```
> tsx -> typescriptreact
> typescriptreact -> typescriptreact
> ```
> 
> Which is fine.
> 
> So I don't really understand the issue.

Wrong way around. It's `register(lang, ft)` which is `register("tsx", "typescript")`, which does get clobbered.

> > Wait... I'm getting confused by this. I don't think it does override it.
> > 
> > ```lua
> > register('typescriptreact', 'tsx')
> > ```
> 
> If I'm understanding the linked issue correctly, the user was having trouble with
> 
> ```lua
> register("typescriptreact", "typescriptreact")
> ```
> 
> That's because currently `language.add(X)` will always call `register(X, X)`

What's the issue with this though? It just means the filetype `typescriptreact` uses the `typescriptreact` parser. I don't see it clobbering anything.

> That being said, I still believe in SRP, but if this solution is preferred I can make a different PR.

In practice this is all in service to make sure `get_parser` works predictably. And that `register` in `add` is just to make sure the parser has at least one filetype.

> It just means the filetype typescriptreact uses the typescriptreact parser. 

The linked issue was that this happened *even when the typescriptreact parser failed to be created*. Which would be solved by https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/25146#issuecomment-1718865993.

The bolder claim (this PR) is that this should just never implicitly happen as a matter of principle. But I'm realizing https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/25146#issuecomment-1718865993 is a much clearer win and I'd be happy to replace this PR with it.

> The linked issue was that this happened even when the typescriptreact parser failed to be created.

What problem did that cause though?

> And that register in add is just to make sure the parser has at least one filetype.

Sure, that's convincing enough for me. Pivoting to #25151

> What problem did that cause though?

recap:
* User `pcall`s `vim.treesitter.start("typescriptreact")`, which fails since there is no `"typescriptreact"` parser, but leaves a side-effect of using `"typescriptreact"` parser (non-existent) for `"typescriptreact"` files. Because they `pcall`ed, they don't realize this is what happened.
* User opens other ".tsx" files and gets thrown errors 'no parser "typescriptreact"' and no highlighting

expectation:
* The `pcall` unwinding shouldn't leave such a side-effect.

> Wait... I'm getting confused by this. I don't think it does override it.
> 
> ```lua
> register('typescriptreact', 'tsx')
> add('typescriptreact')
> ```
> 
> Will create a mapping:
> 
> ```
> tsx -> typescriptreact
> typescriptreact -> typescriptreact
> ```
> 
> Which is fine.
> 
> So I don't really understand the issue.

`M.add` called `M.register(lang, filetype)`, so `M.add('typescriptreact')` called `M.register('typescriptreact', 'typescriptreact')`

so `ft_to_lang['typescriptreact'] = 'tsx'` become incorrect `ft_to_lang['typescriptreact'] = 'typescriptreact'`

I know that part, and explained it, but I didn't understand why that was an issue.

I understand now that the call to `treesitter.add` was incorrect since `typescriptreact` isn't a valid lang.

> so ft_to_lang['typescriptreact'] = 'tsx' become incorrect ft_to_lang['typescriptreact'] = 'typescriptreact'

No this didn't happen. It was actually:

```lua
ft_to_lang['tsx'] = 'typescriptreact'
ft_to_lang['typescriptreact'] = 'typescriptreact'
```

The problem is that `typescriptreact` isn't a valid ts lang.
Which means that #25151 is the correct fix: only register languages that are valid.

title: refactor(treesitter)!: add `language.load()` and soft-deprecate `language.add()`
